definitions.definition: the maintenance of a constant difference in frequency between two or more connected circuits or components.
the alignment of the wheels of a vehicle.
the formation of a conducting path for an electric current over the surface of an insulating material.
the practice of putting schoolchildren in groups of the same age and ability to be taught together.
examples: Japan allows virtually no tracking or ability grouping before high school

definitions.definition: follow the course or trail of (someone or something), typically in order to find them or note their location at various points.
examples: secondary radars that track the aircraft in flight
synonyms: keep in sight; informaltail "he tracked a bear for 40 miles"

definitions.definition: follow and note the course or progress of.
examples: they are tracking the girth and evolution of stars
the storm was tracking across the ground at 30 mph

definitions.definition: (of a stylus) follow (a groove in a record).
(of a film or television camera) move in relation to the subject being filmed.
leave a trail of dirty footprints on a surface.
leave a trail of dirt, debris, or snow from one's feet.
examples: the road salt I'd tracked in from the street

definitions.definition: (of wheels) run so that the back ones are exactly in the track of the front ones.
(of a tunable circuit or component) vary in frequency in the same way as another circuit or component, so that the frequency difference between them remains constant.
assign (a student) to a course of study according to ability.
tow (a boat) along a waterway from the bank.
